context: Act 2A Chapter 2.4 — Journalist contacts Driver with evidence of race fixing going all the way to the top. Choice to help or bury it.

lines.text: A coffee shop in the commercial district. Not the kind Apex executives frequent — the kind with cracked vinyl booths and coffee that tastes like it has opinions.

She is already waiting. Mina Park. Investigative journalist for the Pacific Racing Chronicle. She looks like someone who hasn't slept in a week and has decided that sleep is for people who don't have stories to break.
In front of her: a laptop, a recorder, and a manila folder thick enough to stop a bullet.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Thank you for coming. I know this is a risk for you.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: I've spent eighteen months investigating corruption in the Pacific Rim racing circuit. Fixed races. Bribed officials. Managed outcomes. And every thread leads to the same place.
She opens the folder. Spreadsheets. Emails. Bank transfers. Photographs of people you recognize in meetings they shouldn't be attending.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Dominic Weir. Apex Racing VP. He's been coordinating with race officials and rival teams to manage championship outcomes for at least four years.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: But here's where it gets interesting. Weir doesn't answer to the Apex board. He answers to someone else. Someone who operates outside every corporate structure I've ever mapped.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: The name that keeps appearing in encrypted communications is 'Zero.'
Zero. There it is again. The name that exists in margins and whispers. The invitation on your windshield. The hooded figure on the coastal highway.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: I need a source inside Apex. Someone who has seen things. Someone who can corroborate what I have. Without that, this is just conspiracy theory. With it, it's a story that brings down an empire.

choices.text: I'll help. I've seen enough to know this is real.
I need to talk to Jade first. She deserves to know.
I can't be involved. My career, my contract — there's too much at stake.

lines.label: mina_relieved
lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Thank you. I know what you're risking. Your contract, your career, your safety — all of it.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Here's what I need: access records, meeting schedules, any communication between Weir and outside parties. And if you've seen anything — documents, spreadsheets, conversations — I need dates and details.
You think about the conference room. The projector. The spreadsheet with race results for races that hadn't happened yet.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: One more thing. If they find out you're talking to me, they won't fire you. They'll bury you. Contractual penalties, defamation suits, industry blacklisting. These people don't lose gracefully.

lines.label: mina_warns
lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Jade Winters. Your manager. I've looked into her — she's clean, as far as I can tell. But she's also loyal to Apex. If she goes to Weir before we're ready—

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: Be careful what you share and how you share it. In my experience, even good people do bad things when their world is threatened.

lines.label: mina_understands
lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: I understand. I do. The risk is enormous and the reward is... what? A clear conscience? That doesn't pay rent.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: But let me leave you with this: the races they're fixing? Your championship might be one of them. Not your driving — that's real. But the field you drove against? The opponents who mysteriously underperformed?

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: If this story breaks without your input, your name is in it either way. You can be the whistleblower or the accomplice. There's no third option.

lines.label: investigation_end
lines.text: She closes the folder. Finishes her coffee. Leaves a card on the table — a burner phone number written on the back.

lines.speaker: Mina Park
lines.text: The story runs in three weeks. With or without you.
She leaves. You sit in the booth staring at a cold cup of coffee and a phone number and the reflection of a champion who may have won a fixed championship.
Three weeks. The clock is ticking and the machine is turning and somewhere in the shadows, Zero is watching to see what you do.
